column8: Elixir is missing robust support for commercial tools, such as package hosting and static analysis.  It is also missing a robust ecosystem of libraries to integrate with common tools like Kafka and MySQL.  A multitude of libraries exist, but they are buggy and it's a lot of work to find the best ones.

column119: Elixir did not exist when my company's tech stack was selected.  The existing tech stack is built on Java/C#/Python.  My company is a large enterprise and advocates "standardizing languages" to avoid too many languages in use.  They have the mindset that want to be able to easily hire without training the developers.  My company does not want to consider another language unless there is a proven need for it, and they cannot achieve the same result with the current tech stack.  As well, the structure of people that need to be influenced is huge.  Basically for my team to start using Elixir we would need department-wide support, and several people in my department are reluctant to learn a new language when they do not see job postings for it in the local market.
column143: Deploy to internal servers.  MS Azure is the new future direction.

column24: Learning Elm got me interested in researching more FP options. Elm lead me to Elixir
column59: Haha! All of it. Coming from JS it was all new to me. It was a challenge moving from OOP to FP. It was a challenge of moving from the Wild West of JS to the organization of Elixir. It was hard grasping new concepts like OTP, GenServers, pattern matching, capturing, pinning etc. But I stuck with it, and now I love Elixir. I'm still new, but after the initial challenge, it's all starting to make sense quickly. This is the opposite of of my JS experience. JS was confusing in the beginning. And then it just got even more convoluted.
column118: A lot of people don't know about Elixir. JS for all things owns the conversation everywhere I go. I think people freak out when they have to consider working/learning outside of JS.
